facts: The Giza pyramid complex dates to Egypt’s Old Kingdom (circa 26th century BCE).
The Great Pyramid is attributed to Pharaoh Khufu and was the tallest man‑made structure for millennia.
The three main pyramids are attributed to Khufu, Khafre, and Menkaure.
Limestone statue with a lion’s body and a human head, near the Giza pyramids.
Commonly associated with Pharaoh Khafre (Old Kingdom).
One of the largest religious complexes in the world, expanded over many dynasties.
Dedicated primarily to Amun, with monumental pylons and the Great Hypostyle Hall.
Major temple on the east bank of the Nile in Luxor, linked to Karnak by the Avenue of Sphinxes.
Key associations with the Opet festival in the New Kingdom.
Rock-cut temples built by Ramses II, relocated in the 1960s due to the Aswan High Dam.
Famous for the colossal seated statues at the entrance.
The Step Pyramid of Djoser at Saqqara is considered the earliest colossal stone building in Egypt.
Designed by the architect Imhotep for Pharaoh Djoser.
Temple complex dedicated to Isis; relocated to Agilkia Island during the UNESCO project.
Blend of Pharaonic and later influences.
Houses a vast collection of ancient Egyptian antiquities.
Located in Tahrir Square, Cairo (collections are transitioning to GEM and NMEC).
Medieval Islamic-era fortification in Cairo with panoramic city views.
Includes later monuments such as the Mosque of Muhammad Ali.
Mamluk-era monumental complex famed for its grand scale and stonework.
Built in the 14th century during the reign of Sultan an‑Nasir Hasan.
